instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message:
Liquid damaged board had been worked on already. Possibly SMC reball and other repairs.
Current state:
Green light, all hot and S5 rails present.
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is present.
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22, <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 are fine.
Board is looping with quarter fanspin.

Any idea where to look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message: Look for corrosion. Clock chip is a good suspect also <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is fine. <RESISTOR>R2806</RESISTOR> near clock chip was gone. Replaced that.
Clock chip was looking kind of okay, two pins were darker. I have no replacement from donor board so got it off and soldered it again.
<CHIP>U5410</CHIP> was missing so put one on.
Nothing changed. Still repeated quarter fanspin.
Should I replace clock chip with a new one? Problem is I only could find some on air boards. Is there a chance that they will work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message:
Replace clock chip. It is on all boards 2011+
Also <RESISTOR>R2806</RESISTOR> is no stuff, so should not be there.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message: So by all 2011+ boards you mean macbook air boards too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message: Uhm yeah, did you look at the schematic to see if they are the same?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message:
Checked schematic of a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board and clock chip looked identical so put it on this one. 
This time it turns on but no chime.
CPU vcore is peresent.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message: Well that is bad. Could be anything, probably corrosion under SMC/PCH, but any corroded trace/resistor can cause this. Did you check without the RAM if it beeps? Speaker in the case must be connected, not the one on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b won't turn on (quarter fanspin)
threads.message: No idea, could be anything. As I said, the clock chip was dead so there was liquid there. SMC is right there too, so maybe crap under it.
